title: Ticket #4849: Rewrite all ads leaving collector on single-node pool
description:
(Split off from #4833.)

(It's not really a bug, but an issue when using dual-stack for the HTCondor-CE - so important for the OSG.) In the case where all daemons are on a single node, we can perform address rewriting for all ads leaving the collector. We should loosen the IP address rewriting rules to only match the IP, not the whole sinful.

  • Less aggressive, but would still fix the HTCondor-CE case is only rewriting ads when the sinful strings match or the same shared_port server is used.
remarks:
2015-Jan-16 11:21 by tlmiller:

I don't recall it at the moment -- more later, possibly, or maybe on Tuesday when Alan gets back -- but there's a really good reason we can't rewrite based only on IP address; it may not apply in this special case. I guess we could offer a knob to force the collector to rewrite other people's ads?

2015-Jan-17 07:48:35 by bbockelm:

Yeah, I went back and forth whether to rewrite based on (IP address) or (IP address+port+using shared_port). I picked the less conservative choice in the commit; however, rewriting only sinfuls on the same shared port server would be fine with me and fix this use case.

2015-Jan-26 12:57:40 by adesmet:
What's the use case where this matters? Why do you have single-node pools that provides usable ads to other machines both IPv4 and IPv6?

2015-Jan-27 12:29:05 by bbockelm:
Hi Alan,

The use case here is HTCondor-CE. It is a single-node setup that offers an offsite network service. We'd like to be able to support IPv4-only, IPv6-only, and mixed-mode clients.

In master (or 8.3.3 branch), if IPv6 is enabled, IPv4-only HTCondor-G clients will receive a IPv6 sinful when querying for the schedd. As this would break the majority of clients, we can't really turn on IPv6 for HTCondor-CE right now.

Thanks!

Brian

2015-Feb-09 15:44:00 by adesmet:
After discussion, Todd and I think such a patch is reasonable if it's hidden behind a default-off knob. This is adding a non-trivial amount of complexity to a chunk of code we want to kill. Adding complexity means adding support for the near term. Hopefully by hiding it behind a knob support issues will be minimized.

2015-Feb-11 14:58:51 by bbockelm:
With apologies to Alan and Todd, I'm switching the parent ticket to the OSG master ticket instead of the IPv6 one (as we're calling this an OSG-specific hack).

Too bad we can't derive from multiple tickets :(. Let me know if this will ruin your day.

2015-Feb-16 16:47:54 by adesmet:
Sorry, I had only looked at it briefly and got caught on the big picture issues, which is what Todd and I discussed. Looking closer, I see a number of things that I think should change. My apologies, since on quick glance it looks like these were present in the previous offering.

CODE REVIEW: Needs work.

  • SHARED_PORT_ADDRESS_REWRITING is missing from /src/condor_utils/param_info.in Should come with a comment about being born deprecated.

  • Should we document SHARED_PORT_ADDRESS_REWRITING in the version history and reference? If so, should it include a note that it was born deprecated?

  • my_hostname.cpp line 553: "Sinful commandPortSinful(commandPortSinfulString.c_str());" Initializing with this is misleading; it's never used. Why not move into the loop and re-initialize with *it each time?

  • DaemonCore::CommandSocksSinful:
    • Code indenting is a mix of spaces and tabs. Should be tabs (to match rest of file).
    • Should be clearly marked as deprecated. Do not want new code to use.
    • Partially incompletely duplicates logic in InfoCommandSinfulStringMyself.
      • Rename to match? InfoCommandSinfulStringsMyself?
      • Arguably the difference is okay since the only user doesn't need the full sinfuls. But, the function becomes a landmine.
      • Should one be implemented in terms of the other to ensure they don't drift in implementation? Maybe have InfoCommandSinfulStringMyself(int index) that both call? Or have ICSSM call this and itself return the first element?
    • Is the caching (m_dirty_command_sock_sinfuls) redundant with caching in InfoCommandSinfulStringMyself (m_dirty_sinful)? Almost certainly if one is implemented in terms of the other.

  • SharedPortEndpoint::GetMyRemoteAddresses
    • Piggybacking GetMyRemoteAddress to set up cached information is too clever. Create EnsureInitRemoteAddress which does
      	if( m_remote_addr.IsEmpty() && m_retry_remote_addr_timer==-1 ) {
		RetryInitRemoteAddress();
	}
      and have both GetMyRemoteAddress and GetMyRemoteAddresses call it. (Check for other possible duplicate code. Looks like SharedPortEndpoint::GetMyRemoteAddress has that logic.)

  • SharedPortEndpoint::InitRemoteAddress
    • SharedPortCommandSinfuls should be #defined in condor_includes/condor_attributes.h
    • Possible simplification: Eliminate m_remote_addr entirely. Ensure that the first entry in SharedPortCommandSinfuls is the best default and that the order is preserved when it's m_remote_addrs.push_back()ed. Have SharedPortEndpoint::GetMyRemoteAddress() just return m_remote_addrs.empty()?"":m_remote_addrs[0]. All code wanting m_remote_addrs should call SharedPortEndpoint::GetMyRemoteAddress() instead, or nose around into m_remote_addrs. If SharedPortCommandSinfuls isn't present, fall back on ATTR_MY_ADDRESS and insert it as the only entry in m_remote_addrs. (Or possibly jettison the ATTR_MY_ADDRESS logic entirely since we don't support mixing versions on a single host.)

  • SharedPortServer::PublishAddress
    • Why bother with commandAddresses; could go straight to commandAddressesSL: 
      	for (std::vector<Sinful>::const_iterator it=mySinfuls.begin(); it!=mySinfuls.end(); it++)
	{
		commandAddressesSL.insert(it->getSinful()->c_str());
	}
    • SharedPortCommandSinfuls should be #defined in condor_includes/condor_attributes.h
